values:
Title: This Is The Future
Fandom: Cycling
Pairing: Alexandre Vinokourov/Jan Ullrich
Rating: PG
Disclaimer: This is not at all real, none of it. These events didn't happen to my knowledge. It's almost all speculation (and a bit of my own bitterness toward the whole situation).
Notes: For the epiphany challenge. .

<lj-cut text="This Is The Future">---

He's spent so much time telling reporters, so much time convincing Erik and Cadel, so much time with Jan that he's beginning to believe everything he says. He stands out on the balcony of some hotel and finds himself imagining the tour. Thinking about that maillot jaune and how much he wants it. Not just for himself -- but for the team, for his team, and for Kazachstan.

He thinks he can do it. He can win this year -- he's got a plan and he can read Lance. He has faith in his team, faith in the boys -- even if they're not always there. He leans against the railing, the metal cool against his hands. He can feel that this is the year. He knows what he can do -- what his team can do. He shuts his eyes and lets himself get swept away by strategy, running scenarios through his mind.

The sliding glass doors are jarred, creaking and startling him into reality. His eyes snap open and he turns. One of his teammates is leaning against the glass, facing away from him -- talking and laughing. He stares into the room, past the smiling faces and he sees Jan, head bent, deep in discussion. For some unknown reason Jan looks up and meets Alexandre's gaze. He smiles slightly before returning to his conversation.

It is that look -- the smile -- that reminds Alexandre why he's happy to have Jan back on the team. It reminds him of all the work he's put in convincing the others that this year will be it. But the smile fades from his memory as he keeps watching. Jan turns toward the rest of the team, they look at him, almost enraptured. Jan talks and they all listen.

And Alexandre is struck with the realization -- the feeling he'd been ignoring, that this was not his team. Maybe it never was, but he thinks with sudden bitterness, now it will never be. He knows he's not worth ten million dollars -- that he's just "the Russian" to so many. But he thought he'd proved something last year.

He stands, feeling like a kid with his face pressed up against the glasses, spying on his elders, even though he's backed up against the railing, far from the doors. He stands, watching his future pass him by.

It could have been his year.

And when Jan looks up, looks at him, Alexandre ducks his head away, turning toward the city.

It won't be his year.

Later, after they've all gone back to their own rooms, after the party and the talking, he retreats back to the balcony. He stares without really seeing. And when Jan comes out, light from the hotel room illuminating them, Alexandre can only pretend to be happy. He wants to put everything behind him. He wants to believe this is his -- not Jan's year. But he can't.

Jan's hands on him, fingers kneading at his shoulders. It makes Alexandre want to fold in on himself. But he won't. Instead he'll turn and let Jan kiss him, because they're teammates now.

Title: Pretend
Fandom: Cycling RPS
Pairing: Alessandro Petacchi/Erik Zabel
Rating: PG
Summary: Sitting on a bench, pretending.
Disclaimer: I lie. I have no idea if this happened. I don't actually care if it did. It's none of my business. I write because it's fun.
Notes: For the 'non-alcoholic beverages' challenge. Written in 30 minutes. For Katie. Here are some visual aids: Alessandro, Erik, the two of them (Erik is in white and red, Alessandro is in blue and white). 

<lj-cut text="Pretend">---

He doesn't say anything, just tosses the water bottle at Erik. He opens his bottle, cradling the cap between two fingers as he drinks. He watches Erik, looking for something -- anything. Erik opens his bottle and drinks half of it, wiping his mouth on the back of his hand. Then he looks at Alessandro and gives him a slight nod.

He sits, several inches from Erik. They don't talk, just drink. Erik finishes first, tossing his bottle from hand to hand. Alessandro watches out of the corner of his eye as he slowly drinks the rest of his water. He looks around and, seeing no one nearby, tosses the bottle toward a nearby trashcan. He misses -- the bottle rolls back toward his feet -- and for a moment he thinks Erik might have laughed.

But when he looks over, there isn't even a trace of a smile on Erik's face. He sighs and Erik turns, almost opening his mouth. But he doesn't say anything. They never say anything. They don't talk to each other; they don't even talk about each other. That's just the way it is.

Other sprinters, Alessandro thinks, get along. But he and Erik just can't, which makes what they have even stranger. He runs his hand through his hair, and then puts an arm on the back of the bench. His fingers brush against Erik's jersey. They both know it's one of the most intimate touches they'll ever share in public.

He rubs his fingers against the smooth fabric, and when he closes his eyes for a second he can pretend it's Erik's skin under his fingers. The moment fades when he opens his eyes. Erik's watching him, water bottle twirling in one hand.

Later, when they still won't talk, he'll run his fingers through Erik's hair. He'll breathe into Erik's mouth. And what they share will mean more than they'll ever admit. But here, where the world can almost see, they just pretend.

They sit on a bench, away from the throngs of people. They sit on a bench and pretend that they're just two sprinters and nothing more. They sit on that bench with their discarded water bottles and go through the motions.

Title: Pasta as a Metaphor
Author: Sarah
Fandom: Cycling RPS
Pairing: Baden Cooke/Matt Wilson
Rating: PG-13
Disclaimer: Neither boy is mine. This was written for fun. And to my knowledge these events didn't happen.
Notes: For the 'food' challenge. With everything, it took all 45 minutes. As usual, cross posted in [info]peleton. Part of the AZ-universe.

<lj-cut text="Pasta as a Metaphor">---

It's warm and sunny for January, especially for the morning. They're both up early, for practice, for the sun, for the long ride they'll do later in the day. Matt stretches, his fingers sliding down his legs, already covered in the smooth fabric of his kit. He can hear Baden in the kitchen; cooking the same meal they'll eat for the next, he doesn't even know how long -- nine, ten months.

Pasta.

When he was little he used to enjoy it. Now it's the food he lives on. If he closes his eyes, he can pretend they're getting ready for the tour again. He can hear the van, the hotel, the hundreds of bowls of pasta he'll eat during the three weeks.

But he doesn't. This is different, because it's not the team. It's just the two of them. Pasta isn't a metaphor for life. It's a metaphor for something else. Team, maybe. He thinks about all the pieces of pasta floating, slowly cooking, in the boiling water. It's like their team. Simmering around the edges without a real leader any more. Ready to explode if the moment's right.

He stands and braces himself against the wall, stretching more. Or maybe it's a metaphor for the way Baden makes him feel. Like one tiny piece of pasta, when Baden touches him, he feels pliable. Slick and smooth. He gives way as Baden's hands slide over his body. It could be a metaphor for the way Baden leaves him on edge, more thoughts of boiling over. A whole new meaning to the word 'simmer.'

He's flat on the floor now, pulling one knee toward him, then the other. It could be a metaphor for lust. He hid in the back of the room as they celebrated the night the tour ended. Until Baden found him, and dragged him onto the dance floor. The music was loud and hard, and they were all drunk. Baden's hand slide down his back, pressing their hips together. He can't think of a pasta image without ruining the moment. But it's there, on the edge of his brain. Two smooth pieces, pressed together, sliding across the dance floor.

He stands again, stretching his arms. Or sex. When he's flat on his back and Baden's hovering above him. Hot and sexy and wet. Sliding across the plate and into his mouth as Baden slides across the bed. As Baden slides into him.

But then it's over. Baden's yelling at him to come eat. So he goes, and as he slowly swallows the pasta, he wonders if maybe he's wrong. Maybe it's not a metaphor at all --just food that gets him through the day. Food that keeps them going day after day, kilometer after kilometer, one push of the pedal after another.

They wash the dishes and Matt thinks that it doesn't really matter. Pasta is just pasta. And Baden is just Baden. And he's just Matt. Pasta is what they eat and Matt is what Baden has. Or maybe he has Baden. Then he's reminded of the pasta, curled around each other in the jar where it's stored. Pushed up against each other like the way he sleeps with Baden.

So maybe it's just a metaphor for them. Which is just fine. Because they're going riding today.

Title: Time To Take A Chance
Fandom: Tour De France!RPS
Pairing: Tyler Hamilton/Lance Armstrong
Rating: PG/PG-13
Spoilers: The tour, up to Stage 16.
Summary: It's almost too much and he just wants to give in.
Disclaimer: Neither Lance nor Tyler are mine. This, except for the race and the results, is fiction. I'm almost certain this didn't happen. It's all in good fun.
Notes: While this fic was written for the CLM character development challenge, it was really written for . This fic is cross posted at . Also, the title of this fic is form the song "Sleep All Day" by Jason Mraz. Written in about an hour.

---

It really hurt to breathe. It hurt to move. It even hurt to think, but the latter wasn't something he had much control over. He was lying on his stomach, trying to ignore the pain sliding over his body. He knew it could end, that he could call someone and take the higher dose and everything would slide into oblivion.

It was hell, just getting on the bike in the morning. The vibrations were enough to split his skull. And keeping up? He shook his head as he forced himself to sit up. He was amazed he was still 7th -- no, he was amazed he was still in the race.

He shifted his weight and jarred his shoulder. Yesterday he'd reached for a bottle of water and, without realizing what was happening, he'd pulled at the fracture. Even now it was all he could do to keep the tears at bay. He'd worked so hard for this month, for July. For the Tour. And here he was, struggling to get out of bed and onto his bike.

Two and half weeks in and he couldn't decide if he wanted to quit or start over again. Not that he could redo it, and knowing his luck, he'd fall again. He looked out the window as he got dressed, taking his time, trying not to jar things. He'd eat breakfast then visit the doctors. They'd do tests; make sure he was fit to ride. And he supposed he was, all things considered. But getting back onto the bike … His thoughts trailed off and he shook his head. He hurt and he was tired of riding through the pain. He was tired of pushing himself harder than everyone else. Tired of not getting anywhere but stiff mornings and pity.

But mostly he was tired of the pain. He pulled his shirt on and made a face. He stood, facing the mirror, and looking at himself. He felt 80, not 32. He felt worn out and alone. He knew the team was supposed to do great things, that he was supposed to do great things, but he didn't feel great. He turned away and leaned against the door to the closet, his face resting against the wood. He closed his eyes and suddenly saw how things could be if he just stopped now. He could back out of the race, give up and stop the pain.

It was so tempting. He could see himself reaching out. Calling that number.

The knock on the door made him jump and he banging into the closet door in his haste to answer.

"Damn." He muttered, pulling the door open. He was surprised, having expected to see someone from the CSC team and not, well, not Lance.

Lance stepped into the room. "How're you feeling?" He asked.

Tyler shrugged. He hated admitting weakness, especially in front of Lance.

"Bad?" There was concern in Lance's voice and it made Tyler cringe.

But he found himself nodding. Lance crossed the room and stood in front of Tyler. He didn't say anything, just stood there, as if reading his mind. He was staring deep into Tyler's eyes, and Tyler felt that if Lance asked, he'd bare his soul. He'd stand in the middle of the room and try not to tell the man he almost wanted to beat that he was thinking of quitting -- of giving up.

Lance reached out and touched his face. He trailed his fingers from Tyler's temple, across his cheek, and down his neck, finally resting them on the edge of Tyler's collar.

Tyler felt his stomach churn; he was so close to throwing it all away. He looked at Lance. "How do you do it?" He asked, his voice almost breaking.

Lance blinked and looked startled, but after a moment he smiled. "It's not really how, it's why."

Tyler gritted his teeth, "Fine, why?"

"To prove that I can." Lance replied softly. He reached up and cupped Tyler's cheek in his other hand. "Yesterday. I didn't have a choice. I had to get back on. I had to win."

Tyler shook his head slightly. He opened his mouth, then shut it. It was all too much. Too much pressure, too much pain, too much to prove. He looked away, at the wall -- the closet, anything that wasn't Lance's understanding gaze.

Lance gently turned Tyler's head back toward him. He leaned in and pressed his lips against Tyler's. He lingered, and Tyler didn't pull away. He felt himself sinking, giving in and Lance's tongue slid in and suddenly they were kissing. And for a moment, an instant, nothing hurt. Then they both pulled back and Tyler could feel the pain return, sliding through his system.

Lance's fingers were still on Tyler's face, his neck. Lance leaned in again, and when he spoke, his lips brushed against Tyler's ear. "Don't give up." He whispered. An then stepped away from Tyler, leaving him alone in the middle of the room.

He stood, then took a deep breath. He looked at the phone; he crossed the room and stared at it. Then it rang. He picked it up, started; it was Bjarne telling him to get his ass downstairs and get ready to go. Without thinking, he did, if only out of habit.

He struggled though the warm-ups. He forced himself to do everything they'd talked about the night before. And finally decided that he wouldn't quit, not yet. But if he hurt too much, he'd stop. He made a bet with himself. Ride in the back and give up if he couldn't make it. So he climbed on his bike, certain he was never going to make it.

It started out slowly, pedaling just to get by. He knew Lance had watched him fall back. He'd felt Lance's eyes on him, and he wondered if he'd imagined the disappointment. But it was a bet he'd made with himself. He was so engrossed with his self-pity that he didn't notice the CSC team drop back and surround him. He looked at them; he heard their words, telling him to get moving. He just shook his head, he wasn't ready -- he was injured, and didn't they see that?

But with each push of his feet against the pedals, he felt himself lighten. His eyes were wide open, but all he could see was Lance falling and then flying by them all. He reworked his bet, if he caught up with the pack, and stayed with them, that was good. If it hurt too much, he'd stop. So he pushed past his teammates and caught up with the peleton. He rode with them, slowly gaining. He matched the leaders' pace and turned to glance at Lance.

Lance was grinning at him.

A litter harder, he told himself. He could hear Lance's words echoing throughout his head. Don't give up. And then he looked around him -- there were no riders. Just him. He suddenly worried he'd dropped back again, and then he looked behind. He could just make out the yellow jersey. He had broken away.

I won't give up, he screamed to himself, just watch me. And he rode on. Faster, pushing as hard as he could, pushing through the pain. And when it almost got too much, he'd grit his teeth and think of Lance.

He crossed the line in a blur of tears and pain. And when Lance arms encircled him after the win, the pain didn't matter. All that mattered was that he did it. That he couldn't have done it without Lance, and that he did it because of Lance. But, mostly, he did it for himself. Because he could.

Title: Sunrise
Fandom: Newsies
Pairing: Blink/Mush
Rating: PG-13
Spoilers: None really, but it helps to have seen the movie.
Summary: Early morning in the city.
Disclaimer: Not mine.
Notes: For the sight challenge. Much thanks to for making me thing of Newsies, and thanks to everyone who told me to write this. And a very big thanks to for reading this on such short notice. I used to write Newsies fanfiction (in 1997 - and it was almost all mary-sue), and I hope this makes up for those awful stories I used to write. Written in (hopefully) 45 minutes (with interruptions due to being sick).

---

He tosses and turns. The mattress isn't usually comfortable, and tonight it's keeping him up. He pushes the ragged blanket away and slides off the bunk, trying not to wake anyone. He quietly shuts the door behind him and slips silently down the hallway. He stops in front of a window and stares for a moment. Then, with a deep breath, he pushes the window up and climbs out onto the fire escape, he gently slides the window down, making sure to leave it open, just enough so he can get back in. He climbs up the ladder toward the roof. It creaks, just once, and he holds his breath. He's not sure he wants company.

The moon is still out, but only just. He stares across the city, his city, he pretends. It must have rained, because everything seems to shine in the moonlight. He pads across the roof, ignoring the dirt gathering on his feet. He's seen worse. He finds a spot on the edge of the roof and sits, legs dangling.

He gazes around him, enjoying the almost silence of the morning. He watches people hurrying to get to work, and he wonders if that will ever be him. Not getting ready to sell papers, but putting on a suit and going into some building early in the morning. He shakes his head and sighs. He looks away, trying to find something else to stare at, something happier.

There's nothing. He stares off, watching the sun slowly climb into the sky. Life as a newsboy isn't anything to be proud of, it's hard and he doesn't really like it. He wants something more from life, but he knows that he'll die like he lives. On the streets. He squeezes his eyes shut, so tight he can see his own stars. He takes a deep breath, and it comes out choked, almost like a sob.

"Mush? You okay?"

He nearly falls off the roof. He turns his head, "Blink."

"M'sorry." Blink says and reaches out a hand, pulling Mush back from the edge.

"What're you doin' up here?"

"I heard you." Blink hasn't taken his hand off Mush's shoulder.

"Sorry." He replies, and turns around to face his friend. His toes curl against the edge of the wall he's sitting on.

Blink shrugs, "Couldn't sleep?" He asks, hand falling to his side.

Mush shakes his head.

"Me neither."

Mush stares for a moment, just looking at his friend. He can't remember a time, even though he knows it existed, when he didn't know Blink. And he'd always had that patch over his eye. Mush bites his lip; he can't stop staring.

Blink turns red, and Mush ducks his head. "What?" Blink asks.

"Nothin'."

"You were starin'."

"Sorry."

Blink laughs, "You haven't stared in a while." He takes a step and sits down next to Mush, their bodies barely touching.

Mush's face is red, and he moves, legs dangling off the edge again. "Came up here to watch the sunrise," He states. Then adds, "Be alone."

"Alone?"

He nods and turns to look at Blink again. He hadn't realized he'd spoke aloud. He doesn't answer, and instead lowers his gaze, studying Blink's face again. He's lean and hard. For a moment Mush wonders what he would have looked like if their lives had been different. The thought fades quickly when Blink catches his eye.

"Starin' again?"

Mush just grins, trying to mask the shy smile. He turns away; he hopes the sun will cover the blush rising on his face.

"You never asked." Blink states.

Without thinking, Mush turns his head with a jerk. "What?"

"About this." He gestures to the patch over his eye.

"Thought you'd tell me someday."

Blink nods and tilts his head slightly. "Now's as good as any, I suppose." He takes a deep breath and looks out over the city for a moment, then back to Mush. "There's really nothin' to tell. I've always had it. Since I was little."

Mush opens his mouth, but can't come up with anything to say.

"Somethin' happened. I mean, when I was born. Could never see right out that eye." He says, voice low.

"So, you're ..." He can't finish his question out loud. Blink can't see. He'd never considered that.

"Blind in one eye." Blink answers and turns toward Mush. "Can't miss what I don't know."

Mush nods, more to himself than at Blink. He stares again, then, without really thinking, he reaches out and traces the patch with his finger. He expects Blink to push his hand away, but nothing happens. He traces the skin around the patch. He fingers the edge, then meets Blink's eye.

"Can I?" He asks, voice soft.

Blink nods, his eye follows the arm, then he goes back to watching Mush.

Mush slips his finger under the edge of the patch and gently lifts it up. It slides off easily and falls into his hand. The leather is soft and worn; he lets it dangle from his fingers for a moment, before looking back up. Blink looks different with both eyes visible. Mush transfers the patch to his other hand, then reaches out and traces the outline of where the patch was pressed against Blink's face. The skin is red and raw, as if the patch was trying to grow into the skin. Blink's eye looks almost normal, except it never focuses on him. Mush feels himself flush again, as if he's been caught staring again and is embarrassed.

Blink reaches out and grabs Mush's hand, the one holding the patch. He twines his fingers with the strap of the patch, and Mush's fingers.

Mush can't pull his gaze away. "Why me?" He asks, even though that's not the real question.

Blink closes his eyes for a moment, "Why not?"

Mush traces the side of Blink's face with his thumb.

Blink turns his face toward Mush's hand; he licks his lips and his tongue brushes Mush's thumb. He opens his eyes. "It's almost over."

"Sunrise?" Mush asks, his hand slides down Blink's face and rests on his neck.

"This." He gestures to the lodging house, the city.

Mush gets it. He nods. "Couldn't sleep." He says, quietly.

Blink nods.

Mush slides his fingers around to the back of Blink's neck. He brings their heads together. It hurts his eyes to keep them open when they're so close, but he can't shut them. "What're your plans ... For after?"

Blink shrugs, and rests his forehead against Mush's. "You?

"Nothin'." Mush whispers, his hand falls from Blink's neck. It rests on his friend's leg.

"We could go west." Blink offers.

"We?" Mush's eyes grow wide, he pulls back a bit.

Blink nods. "You an' me."

"Why me?" He asks again, even though he already knows. After all, he thinks, they are best friends.

"'Cause." Blink replies, then slips his hand around Mush's head and presses his fingers lightly against the base of Mush's neck. "This. Us." He whispers, and then kisses Mush.

After a moment Blink pulls back.

Mush stares, then smiles slowly. "Us." He replies, then watches as Blink moves to put the patch back on. "Wait." He says, and lifts his hand, he presses his fingers to the side of Blink's face, holding him still. He takes it in, staring, remembering. Then, ignoring how it might seem to someone watching, he leans forward and presses his lips against Blink's eye. He sits back.

Blink flashes him a smile and then replaces the patch. His hand slides back into Mush's as he turns toward the sunrise.

Mush squeezes Blinks hand, and stares. In the morning sun, the city almost glows. The work is hard, and he still hates it. But maybe not everything's so unhappy.

Title: Private
Pairing: Roger/Marcus
Fandom: Harry Potter
Rating: PG-13
Spoilers: None
Summary: It's a private moment.
Disclaimer: The characters belong to JKR and Warner Brothers.
Notes: Written for the voyeur challenge. For Jordan, because they always are.

<lj-cut text="Private">---

Even watching him feels like being a voyeur. It shouldn't matter, because it's not like they don't spend every day together. Because, he reminds himself, it's not like he hasn't seen him naked, jacking off, or whatever. And, he thinks, they've fucked -- more than once, more often than not. But it doesn't stop him from feeling like a voyeur.

He stands in the doorway -- watching, waiting. He doesn't know why he doesn't just go in. It's been hours since the Ministry men left, hours since Roger's been sitting there -- not moving, barely breathing. But he doesn't go in, he can't bring himself to walk those few steps.

It's a private moment, a private moment that's turned into three hours of avoiding. Three hours of trying to convince himself that it's okay to walk over to that couch, To walk over to the couch and run a hand through Roger's hair. To sit next him and touch his arm, let him know that it'll be fine.

But he can't. Because he feels like he's intruding -- interrupting. And that's so unlike him, so unusual, that he's still standing there. Watching.

Until Roger turns around and Marcus sees the pain and the hurt. The loss mixed with abandon and loneliness. He takes a few steps and he's there. He sits next to Roger, resting his hand on top of Roger's.

They don't talk; he doesn't lie and say things will be fine. He still feels like a voyeur, but he doesn't mind so much now.

Title: Show Love With No Remorse Pairing: Roger/Marcus Fandom: Harry Potter Rating: PG-13 Spoilers: None Summary: He doesn't know. Disclaimer: The characters belong to JKR and Warner Brothers. Notes: Written for the tenses challenge. Written in under 60 minutes -- broken up into two sections, though. Thanks to Dae and Katie for giving the tenses a once over. For Jordan, because they always are. The title of the story is from Dosed by Red Hot Chili Peppers. The italics represent narration. --- He doesn't know what Roger sees in him. Why Roger stays around, sleeps in his bed, loves him. --- "I love you," Roger had said. Marcus had stared at Roger. "I don't love." He'd said, voice barley audible. "I know." Roger had said, softly. He'd crossed the room and sat on the couch next to Marcus. "Then how can you?" He'd asked, avoiding Roger's gaze. Roger had reached out and touched Marcus's face, tilting his head toward him. "Just because you don't love me doesn't mean you can't." Marcus had looked away, unable to mean Roger's eyes. Later that night, when they were almost asleep, he kissed Roger with his eyes closed. --- He doesn't love because he never knew love. He never knew it until Roger. And now he wants to love him. --- They sit on the couch again. Marcus's hand covers Roger's. He turns, studying Roger's profile. It he could love -- he banishes that thought. But before he can stop himself, he opens his mouth. "I don't deserve your love." Roger looks at Marcus. "What?" "I do not deserve what I can't return." He forces himself to look at Roger. "I don't care." Roger replies. Marcus blinks and looks away. Later when they're lying in bed, Roger rolls over and Marcus kisses him with his eyes closed. --- He doesn't love Roger, but he would die for him. He would give up his whole existence for Roger. --- The day will come when Marcus will be forced to choose between Roger and his destiny. The day will come when Marcus will have to give up everything he'd been trained for. The day will come when Marcus will sit on that couch next to Roger and tell him his final choice. And that night, when they're trying to figure out their future, Marcus will kiss Roger with his eyes open. --- He still doesn't know why Roger loves him. But it doesn't matter, because Roger loves him; because he'd give up everything for Roger.

Title: You'll Find a Way Somehow
Fandom: 2003 MTV RW/RR Battles of the Sexes
Pairing: Shane/Antoine
Rating: PG-13
Spoilers: Up through episode 16
Summary: This is the last day together ...
Disclaimer: These boys are not mine. Most of the events didn't happen. The song doesn't belong to me, either.
Notes: Apparently two fics weren't enough. I had to write more. Written for Jordan and Katie.
Song: The Last Song by The All-American Rejects. Lyrics here

<lj-cut text="You'll Find a Way Somehow">---

Antoine clutches the Ion in his hands. He knows what he's going to do and he knows why. And he knows, much to his chagrin, exactly what's going to happen. They didn't even have to talk about it.

So why is he so upset when Shane gives it back to him?

Because he'll miss Shane. The way they talked and cheered each other on. He'll miss their friendship. But, he thinks as they're hugging, face pressed against Shane's shoulder, it's more than just friendship.

It's not love and he'll probably see Shane again. Maybe invite him to Vail and Cancun. But it still hurts. And Shane still has to go. And he has to stay, and maybe he can win it all. For Shane.

But for now it's the end. And Shane will go back to Hugh. But the offer will be open. The unspoken offer, the looks exchanged.

He clenches his hands in fists as the van with Shane pulls away. And he hopes that this isn't the last time he'll see him. He hopes that they'll figure things out. He hopes that somehow it'll work and one day he'll wake up in Shane's arms.

He hopes that somehow things will work out. And as Shane waves to him, he can wonders if Shane's thinking the same thing.

Title: Memories in Pink and Blue
Fandom: RPS
Pairing: Clay Aiken/Sondre Lerche
Rating: PG-13/Light R
Summary: That's how he'll remember him.
Disclaimer: They are really, really, not mine and this is definitely not true. I'm almost certain Clay doesn't know who Sondre is. Sondre's been touring in US, so I like to think that he might know who Clay is.
Notes: Don't ask. I mean, really, don't. It's far too complicated and weird. You can download Sondre's songs off of Kazaa and visit his website. I highly recommend his music. Also, I don't know if he thinks in English or Norwegian, but of course, I don't know Norwegian, so English it is. Written in about 30 minutes for the complementary colors challenge.

<lj-cut text="memories in pink and blue">---

He thinks that the next time he sees Clay that he's going to be dressed a lot nicer. He's going to wear clean trousers and a pressed shirt. He's not going to be sweaty and wearing whatever he just sang in.

And he's right.

The next time he sees Clay, he's wearing pajamas. There's a knock on his hotel room, in some city he can't remember, and when he opens it, in his simple gray pajamas, he almost stops breathing.

On the other side of the door is Clay.

He has to remind his heart to beat, his lungs to work. When the door shuts and Clay's kissing him, he thinks that he doesn't have to remind himself how to do this. He's kissing, pushing at Clay's shirt, wanting to touch skin. And then his pajama top falls to the ground on top of Clay's t-shirt. They're bodies are pressed together and Sondre's not thinking about anything except how never expected this to be the next time he saw Clay.

Later, when he's curled up in Clay's arms, he thinks about the two of them. He thinks of himself in blues, bright and soft light blues. Like the colors of his website. He thinks of Clay in terms of pale pinks; the way his own face looked the first time they kissed.

He thinks about how different they are, how Clay's so famous. Famous in ways Sondre will never be, never really wants to be. And then he thinks about when he leaves the States it'll probably be over.

But he'll always have those memories in blue and pink.

Title: Almost
Fandom: CFB/NFL
Pairing: Jordan/Carson Palmer
Rating: PG
Disclaimer: Not mine, not real, etc.
Notes: Carson plays fo rthe Bengals and Jordan plays for University Of Texas At El Paso.

<lj-cut text="Almost">---

Carson calls because he's supposed to.
Carson calls because he can't be there.
Carson calls because he watched the game. He watched and he saw that last quarter.

He calls because he loves his brother.

He calls because he isn't there. He calls and it's not enough. He calls and he can hear the ache in Jordan's voice. The way his words break off when he's upset, the way his sentences are clipped. The way Carson doesn't have to see to know Jordan is silently crying.

He fills Jordan's head with promises. With words of love and how things'll work out and this happened for a reason. He talks until he knows Jordan's stopped crying. He talks longer, babbling about nothing, about his next game, about Jordan's classes. He talks until he runs out of things. He talks until his voice is raw.

He knows it doesn't help. He knew it wouldn't. It couldn't.

But, when he hangs up the phone, he knows Jordan will sleep a little bit better. And that's almost enough.

Almost.

Title: Change
Fandom: NFL
Pairing: Peyton/Eli Manning
Raiting: PG
Disclaimer: Not mine, not real, etc.
Notes: Eli is fourteen and Peyton is nineteen. 

<lj-cut text="Change">

---

When he was fourteen, he got sick. It was nothing, just the flu, but his parents were out of town and Peyton was the only one at home. It was a few years before Peyton went pro, before he left Eli.

Eli had spent hours trying not to let Peyton know he was sick. Didn't want to ruin Peyton's plans for their empty house. He knew how much his brother had been looking forward to the weekend.

But it was too hard to hide.

Peyton found him hunched over the toilet puking his guts out. He'd canceled the party and spend the night taking care of Eli. He hadn't even laughed when Eli hurt so much he cried.

After he'd stopped throwing up. After the fever reduced, Peyton helped Eli into clean pajamas and down the hall. Peyton's room was always neat.

Peyton had pushed back the covers and Eli crawled into Peyton's bed, only half-surprised when Peyton had followed him.

He didn't remember falling asleep, but he woke up curled around Peyton. And then he knew, somehow, that things had changed.

Title: Glimpse of the Future
Fandom: NFL
Pairing: Peyton/Eli Mannging 
Rating: PG
Disclaimer: Not mine, not real, etc.

<lj-cut text="Glimpse of the Future">---

Easy as phone calls, Eli thinks. His brother throws, passes and it's easier than calling him. Watching Peyton, if he gets the chance, is nothing like phone calls. Nothing like the long pauses and meaningless conversations.

Not that talking about football is necessarily meaningless, but most of his life is -- has been -- spent that way.

He liked a break.

Peyton never gives him one.

Even their emails are filled with football. It's tiresome. When they were little, he could always count on Peyton to distract him. But not now.

Peyton has become something else, like their father. Obsessed and Eli wonders if that's his future, too. He doesn't want that, but he doesn't think he can escape it. At least, not as long as he keeps calling Peyton. IF he stopped, maybe.

But he won't. He loves his brother too much.

So he sits and watches. Peyton on his TV is smiling and grinning. Eli almost wishes he'd been there. But he wasn't and so it's surreal, almost unreal. The Peyton on his TV is the Peyton who exists now. Not the boy whose bed he'd crawl into when thunderstorms were too loud. When his parents fought. When one of them got hurt on the field. The Peyton on Eli's TV is a stranger.

Except he sees himself. The way he'll be.

His life is Peyton's, only without the glory.

Title: Sometimes Fandom: SWAT RPS Pairing: Colin Farrell/Jeremy Renner Rating: PG Disclaimer: All I know is that they're good friends and drink together. Everything else is fiction. No money is being made. Notes: For Diane. Written in less than 45 minutes for the couch challenge. Cross posted in . --- Sometimes they don't talk. Colin sits on one end of the couch; feet tucked under him, drinking beer and flipping channels. Jeremy finds himself on the other end, feet pressed up against Colin's ass, drinking beer and pretending to read -- whatever happens to be around. The paper, a book, most often, though, magazines. He doesn't really understand how Colin ended up on his couch. Well, the mechanics he understands. Walking, sitting, all that he gets. It's the fact that sometimes he'll wake up and Colin's still there. Sleeping, drinking, whatever. And he just goes about his day, oddly comforted in the fact that Colin's taking good care of his couch. Until he stops and starts thinking about it. Because it's really fucking weird. He knows Colin's his best friend. But they're sort of living together, if the pile of Colin's clothes he washed yesterday is an indication of cohabitation. Not that he minded, washing the clothes. But it was weird, finding pants that weren't his, in his basket. And then he found himself thinking that next time Colin would have to wash the clothes, because he's done in three weeks in a row. But then Colin paid for dinner and whatever it was they did after. He can only drink so much before he's under the table and Colin's laughing. And everything was just fine. But that really doesn't explain why Colin's sitting on his couch, drinking and watching TV. He reaches down for his own beer and looks over the top of his Sports Illustrated. He stares at Colin and wonders what he's thinking. He doesn't really care what's on the TV, except to file it away for future reference. What he cares about, because he's finally given in and admitted that he cares, is the fact that he's so happy Colin looks comfortable on their -- his -- couch. Colin shifts and downs the rest of his beer. He looks over at Jeremy and grins. "Want another?" He asks. Jeremy shakes his head and watches Colin pulls himself off the couch. He stretches out, pretending to read that magazine again. But he's thinking about their friendship, and when it changed from 'friends who drink' to 'friends who drink and hang out' and then finally to 'friends who drink and hang out and live together." Sometimes they don't talk, which is okay with Jeremy. But sometimes they do talk. And that's okay too. It's what might happen next that he wonders about. But he doesn't find out, because Colin's back. He lifts up Jeremy's feet and slides under them, letting them rest on his knees. He sips his new beer and starts talking about whatever's on TV. And Jeremy finds he has to pay attention, so he tosses the magazine on the floor. And that moment he was lost in before just disappears.

unicorns lit: many waters sandy/dennys pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to madeline l'engle --- He's exhausted. His eyes flutter shut -- if he can just concentrate, he'll be asleep in seconds. But the door bangs open and Sandy comes running into the room. "Did you hear?" Sandy shouts, propelling himself toward Dennys. He forces his eyes open, he can barely focus. "What?" He asks, the word slow on his tongue. His eyes slide shut again. He hears Sandy's voice, not as clear as before -- muffled by the sleep that's just out of reach. He hears words, "college" and "acceptance," and maybe "letter." And some part of him is overjoyed because they've both gotten into college. But all he can do is yawn and mumble. "Unicorns?" He hears Sandy ask, loudly. He forces an eye open, "Wha?" He says, word cut off by a yawn. He hears Sandy tell him he was talking about unicorns. He thinks, 'he?' then he realizes Sandy means himself, not Sandy. He's tired and confused and he thinks he ought to tell Sandy that he sees them -- unicorns -- when he's this tired. But he can't even muster up the energy to keep his eyes open, much less talk. He opens his mouth and hope he says "G'way. Sleep." But he's not sure. Then he feels Sandy moving around, close to him. And he thinks he must have been hearing things, because Sandy's still there. And then the room goes quiet. He starts to drift off and he sees a unicorn behind his eyelids. He's almost asleep when he feels something -- Sandy -- curling around him. Sandy nuzzles his neck, and the last thing he remembers, even after the unicorn, is Sandy. "I see them too." Sandy whispers, lips hot on his skin. And then he's asleep.

chocolate evenings lit: many waters sandy/dennys pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to madeline l'engle --- The house was quiet -- they'd been left home alone again. They don't mind, especially when it's winter. The hot chocolate had been moved to the kitchen and both boys were grateful. Sandy put the water on and watched as Dennys went about fixing the mugs. Eventually the water boiled and he poured it, filling their mugs nearly to the brim. They took their mugs into the living room. "Read?" Dennys asked, blowing on his mug, watching the steam rise. Sandy nodded and settled onto the couch. Dennys sprinted to their room and returned shortly with two books. He handed one to Sandy and then sat on the couch, leaning against his brother. They read until the chocolate was gone. Sandy yawned. "Do you think they'll be home soon?" He asked. Dennys shrugged, setting his book down. Sandy pushed Dennys away from him and took both their empty mugs to the kitchen. He returned to the living room and grabbed his book. Dennys looks at him and then took his own book and followed Sandy to their room. "You think they're having fun?" He asked. Sandy laughed, "They're shopping again." He watched as Sandy changed into pajamas and he soon changed too. Sandy crawled into his bunk and watched Dennys. "Will we live together?" He asked quietly, breaking the silence. Dennys looked up from his pile of dirty clothes. "At school?" "Whenever. Always." Sandy's arms were crossed, resting above the covers and on his chest. Dennys thinks for a moment, "Do you want to? "Yes." He said, without giving it a second thought. Dennys smiles slightly, "We're just like the rest of our family, then." Sandy looks at his brother, "Not normal." Dennys nods. "I wonder why." He laughs and pushes the cover back, uncovering Sandy. Sandy moves over, letting Dennys climb in with him. "I hope we do." He whispers in Denny's hair. "We will." Dennys says, pulling Sandy's arms, and the blankets, around him.

together lit: many waters sandy/dennys r not mine. all fiction. characters belong to madeline l'engle --- The room is hot and Sandy's tired of sweating. He slips his shirt off and tosses it on the floor. He angles the fan at his bunk and lies down. He's almost asleep when Dennys stumbles into the room. Sandy watches Dennys slip of his clothes: shirt and pants. "Hot." Sandy says, lazily. Dennys turns, "Extremely." He walks in front of Sandy, blocking the fan. "Blocking the fan." Sandy says, slightly annoyed. "I know." He walks toward the bed, stopping at the edge. Sandy reaches out and grabs Dennys hand. He pulls his brother toward him. Dennys sits on the edge of the bed, watching Sandy. "Are they gone?" "Out." Sandy smiles and tugs at the waistband of Dennys' boxers. Dennys moves closer to Sandy, "It's not too hot?" He murmurs. "Not for us." Sandy says as his fingers slide along Dennys' skin. Dennys shifts so he's almost hovering over Sandy. Sandy's fingers slide down his brother's chest and he pushes the boxers down. Dennys gasps slightly when Sandy's fingers touch him. He sits up, head angled away from the springs on the top bunk, and pulls at Sandy's pants. Sandy lifts his hips and then they're both naked. The kiss is deep and Sandy thinks that it might make him come right there. But it doesn't and so he kisses Dennys back, sliding his tongue inside his brother's mouth. They move faster, bodies pressed and arching against each other. Sandy comes panting, his brother's name is on his lips. Dennys comes a few seconds after, gasping Sandy's name. waiting lit: post-many waters sandy/dennys pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to madeline l'engle --- They're lying in bed together, just the two of them. The house is quiet, empty. Christmas vacation has begun and they haven't seen each other in weeks. The family is out shopping, leaving them -- as always -- to their own devices. Only now they're both old enough to know better. Instead of exploring, taking a walk, or ever doing work for their classes next semester, they lie in bed. Sandy's hand covers Dennys, their fingers entwined. He wants to roll over and kiss Dennys. He wants to feel his brother move against - with -- him. He wants to be able to gasp his brother's name when he comes. And he knows Dennys wants the same. But neither of them move. They're in limbo. Waiting for the right moment to let it all go. It's not time, they both know it. They need to get used to each other again. To remember. Each time it takes a little longer and the fear it won't happen again almost outweighs the desire -- the need. But it will happen, this time. So they wait.

unwavering certainty lit: chronicles of narnia: the last battle edmund/eustace pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to cs. lewis written for the flash-forward contre la montre challenge. --- He see everything, their future. And he knows with an unwavering certainty that it's the future. He sees crashing and fire and flashing lights. And from a safe distance he watches the world end. He watches everything fall apart, and then he watches them, his family - Lucy, Peter, his parents, even Eustace. He finds that they're all there with him. Safe and alive. Then he watches the other people, swirling around him, they're not quite there, slowly some of ascend, at least that's how it feels, with him. Then he watches the rest, including Susan, disappear. He reaches out for her, trying to grab her hand and bring her with him, but his hands pass through her. He turns, stricken, to his brother, toward Eustace and they just smile. He tried to yell, tell them what's going on, but nothing comes out. And then Eustace's fingers grasp his and he slides into calmness, the fear and fury just on the edges of his mind. As Eustace tugs him closer, he tries to remember what he was upset about, and for a brief moment he sees the crash again then it's gone and he can't remember. Then suddenly he's awake. He's sitting in bed, wearing only his pajama bottoms. He gulps in air and then rubs his eyes. He looks around him, eyes adjusting to the darkness. He remembers where he is and he looks down and sees Eustace sleeping next to him. He reaches out and brushes his fingers against skin, fingers trailing down Eustace's spine. Eustace stirs and Edmund's fingers freeze, but Eustace doesn't wake. Edmund breathes a sigh of relief; he's not ready to share his dream just yet. He sinks back into bed, pulling the covers around him, and then curls up next to Eustace. He slides his arm around Eustace, and in his sleep, Eustace tugs Edmund's arm tight around him, and laces his fingers with Edmund's. For a moment Edmund wonders if Eustace is a wake, but the gentle sleep-sigh tells him otherwise. Edmund closes his eyes and tries to erase the fiery wreck from his mind. He pictures a house, a big white house with three bathrooms and six bedrooms. He forces his mind to envision Eustace in the kitchen, cooking. He pretends that he's in the other room, folding laundry or cleaning, or something. This is the future he wants, the future he needs. He feels sleep pushing at the edges and he tries to ignore it a little longer. He pretends he can see Eustace crawling into bed and he watches himself tumble after. He can almost hear his own laughter. But then he feels himself yawn. He tries pushing the nightmare away, but it's right there, forcefully persistent. And as he falls asleep, he tightens his arm around Eustace, hoping that this time it'll end differently.

making do with kings and princes lit: chronicles of narnia: the horse and his boy cor/corin pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to cs. lewis --- Cor watches his brother carefully, trying to learn. "You're watching me again." Corin says, turning around. He's wearing only his trousers. Cor's face flushes red. "I'm sorry." He's already dressed in his pajamas. Corin laughs and sits on the bed. "What are you expecting to see?" Cor shakes his head, "Not see. Learn." He bites his lip and pulls his knees up to his chest. "Learn what?" Corns asks, shifting so he's facing his brother. "I'm going to be king, aren't I?" Corin nods. "I should learn to behave as such." Cor doesn't look at Corin. "Aravis doesn't seem to care." Cor glares at his brother, "It's not about her." Corin sighs, "Then what is it about?" He runs a hand through his hair and looks at Corin. "I am not a king. I will never be." Corin reaches out and grabs Cor's hand, sliding his fingers along Cor's knuckles. "I don't want to be." His voice is quiet. Corin's voice catches. "You haven't any choice." Cor raises his gaze and looks at Corin. "Everything will change, you know." Corin moves closer, "You'll be a king and I'll still be a prince." "Isn't that what you wanted?" Cor asks, sliding his fingers between Corin's. Corin signs, "Of course." He wants to say something more, but he doesn't. Cor pulls his brother toward him, "But that's not what you -- we -- meant." He states. Corin nods, gently touches Cor's face. "We'll make do." Cor turns his head slightly, lips brushing Corin's hand. Corin pushes Cor back onto the bed and crawls across it, lying down next to his brother. They curl around each other and sleep.

changed forever lit: chronicles of narnia (through book four) edmund/eustace pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to cs. lewis --- With a blanket wrapped around him, Edmund watches the snow fall. He remembers his first visit to Narnia. He can see Lucy, running in the snow. And for the first time he's hit with more guilt that he can ever remember feeling. He stares out the window and tries to forget the witch and how poorly he treated Lucy, and later Peter and Susan. He's so absorbed in his thoughts that he doesn't hear the knock or the eventual creak of the door opening. Eustace stares at Edmund, trying to figure out what he's doing. He wants to cross the room, as what's wrong, but he doesn't. He just watches. Edmund finally sees Eustace's reflection in the window. He doesn't turn around. "The first time I went to Narnia I was simply awful." Eustace doesn't know how to answer. So he just nods and wonders if Edmund has more to say. He does. "I betrayed those closest to me." He says, pulling his knees to his chest, wrapping his arms around them, blanket falling to the floor. Eustace sucks in a breath, then crosses the room. He sits on the window seat, next to Edmund. Edmund doesn't look at Eustace. "You weren't the only one." He finally says, quietly. Eustace moves closer, fingers brushing Edmund's hand. Edmund grabs Eustace's hand and laces their fingers together. They sit there, watching the snow. The two of them, changed forever.

changes, moments and two people lit: chronicles of narnia (through book four) edmund/eustace pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to cs. lewis --- He trails his fingers along Eustace's skin. He doesn't remember when it began. He thinks it might have happened on his last visit, the second visit that was the last. On the island. That moment they shared. But now they're older and things have changed. He sees Eustace more often then Peter and Susan, and even Lucy. They only mentioned it once, when Eustace said he'd gone back again, a few years earlier. Edmund had remembered thinking that Lucy would have been pleased to hear that, but he'd never told her. Eustace's lips on his skin distract him. He's reminded of how much his cousin has changed. How much he himself had changed. How much time has passed. How they've grown up. Shared things, lives. But he'll always remember Narnia. Because, no matter how much things have changed, they'll always that that moment. Eustace asks him what he's thinking. Edmund tells him he's remembering things past and times gone by. And Eustace looks at him and says he remembers and oh, how times have changed. Edmund nods and then says that they've grown, they're different. Eustace looks at him, pressing his lips to Edmund's throat and whispers that they'll always have that moment. They'll always have this. And they'll always have each other. Because, though things change, they'll go through it together.

he feels so alone lit: chronicles of narnia edmund/eustace & edmund/peter pg-13 not mine. all fiction. characters belong to cs. lewis written for the contre la montre lyrics challenge. the song used is "poetic tragedy" by the used. --- He'd always known that Edmund loved Peter more. But he always thought it was a brother thing. So he'd convinced himself that it was something more ... Something deeper, something special. But now he knows he was just kidding himself. Just pretending. --- He sits across the room, watching Peter watch Edmund tell some story. Neither of them are listening to Edmund, but that doesn't really matter, they rarely ever do. Eustace watches the way Peter's eyes focus on different parts of Edmund's body. His hands first, then the curve of his shoulder. And then Eustace has to stop watching, because he'll end up jealous. And, as Lucy likes to tell him, jealousy isn't very becoming on him. So instead he remembers. He closes his eyes and thinks about the way Edmund's eyes glow when he's excited. The way the sun makes his hair shimmer. The way the moon shines off of Edmund's body when they're both lying outside, naked. And then he realizes that he can't remember the last time he saw Edmund naked. The last time he felt Edmund touch him. And he curses himself for getting lost in his memories. So he opens his eyes and the first thing he sees is Peter's hand on Edmund's shoulder. He can feel his heart break, but not so much that anyone would notice. Until he looks at Edmund. --- Edmund has always loved Peter. And Eustace has to accept that, to move on with his life. But he can't, because there's no where to go. If things were different -- if they were different, he could be with Edmund and Peter would be off at school. But things aren't different, and he can't even end his own misery. So he just sits across the room, watching. And pretend that they had something more. Something special.
